data.title: Weather Alerts
data.text:
Flood Warning

Caledonia, VT

Essex, VT

Orleans, VT

Washington, VT

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Portions of central and northeast Vermont, including the following counties, in central Vermont, Washington. In northeast Vermont, Caledonia, Essex and Orleans. * WHEN...Until 900 AM EDT. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. The East Branch of the Passumpsic at East Haven is at action stage of 6.0 feet and is expected to exceed minor flood stage of 6.5 feet in the next couple of hours. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 618 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated an area of heavy rainfall across the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 0.50 inches are possible in the warned area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Lyndon, St. Johnsbury, Wheelock, Sheffield, Stannard, Lyndonville Village, Sutton, Danville, Willoughby, Walden, Greensboro Bend, West Burke Village, Glover, Greensboro, Burke, Barton, Kirby, Westmore, Hardwick and Newark. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Flood Watch

Coos, NH

Grafton, NH

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible. * WHERE...A portion of northern New Hampshire, including the following areas, Northern Carroll, Northern Coos, Northern Grafton and Southern Coos. * WHEN...From 5 PM EDT this afternoon through Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...Repeated rounds of heavy rainfall will bring that potential for excessive runoff. This will bring an increased risk of flash flooding as well as flooding of small streams. Widespread mainstem river flooding is not expected. The heaviest rainfall is expected to fall this evening through the wee hours of Saturday morning.

Clinton, NY

Essex, NY

Franklin, NY

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible. * WHERE...Much of northern New York, including the following counties, St. Lawrence, Franklin, western Clinton, and western Essex. * WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Widespread showers with embedded thunderstorms are expected across much of northern New York as the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby cross the region. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 5 inches will cause flooding of urban, low-lying, and poor drainage areas with the potential for scattered flash flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Addison, VT

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible. * WHERE...A portion of central Vermont, including the following county, Eastern Addison. * WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Widespread showers with embedded thunderstorms are expected to continue today into this evening as the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby cross the region. Total rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are expected, which may cause localized flash flooding over the higher terrain of eastern Addison County, Vermont. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Caledonia, VT

Chittenden, VT

Essex, VT

Franklin, VT

Lamoille, VT

Orleans, VT

Washington, VT

* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible. * WHERE...Portions of central, northeast, and northwest Vermont, including the following counties, Washington, Caledonia, Essex, Orleans, Lamoille, eastern Chittenden, and eastern Franklin. * WHEN...From 8 AM EDT this morning through Saturday morning. * IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Widespread showers with embedded thunderstorms are expected across much of northern and central Vermont as the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby cross the region. Total rainfall amounts of 1.5 to 3.5 inches with locally higher possible will cause streams and possibly rivers to rise sharply, and flooding may occur. Damaged infrastructure and clogged culverts and drainage ditches may be especially vulnerable to additional flood damage. - Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
